last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90127772
>And yet the record is 32 consecutive reds on a fair roulette
Yeah, out of trillions of sets of 32 spins. That's different than only having one set of spins. "unlikely things happen all the time" is accounted for by multiplying a by the number of samples in your sample of samples, and then any tail result is properly interpreted as typical. But if you get a new roulette wheel in the break room and your boss asks you if it's biased based on only that data, the answer is still yes. The fact that you'd expect it to even out if it is indeed fair if you take more samples is a true but irrelevant statement since real-world data is usually supply-constrained. You go ahead and use your RNG that always gives 0 for crypto, I won't stop you

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
People like it a lot. But from my point of view, it's worse than Java in just about every way*. (I say this as someone who hates Java)
What compels people to use Go? What could change my mind about it?

*A breakdown:
>Syntax
Go's syntax is nicer in many small ways but is worse in several big ways, like lacking an if-else operator, having abhorrent syntax for anonymous functions, and the for-each loop being limited to Go's builtin collections. Surprisingly, Java wins here.
>Interfaces
Go lets you implement interfaces for "external" structs, which is nice. OTOH, having interfaces get implemented implicitly was a bad idea. It's a tossup.
>Generics
They're simply worse in Go
>performance
roughly equal as far as I can tell.
>ecosystem
Java wins big
>misc
Go has a lot of genuinely retarded shit in it, like defer. This is a big con
virtual threads are kind of a plus for go except that many previous use cases for them in Go were solved by having generics and Java has them anyway as of Java 19
memes about union interfaces (e.g. constraints.ordered) could go under either interfaces or generics depending on how you see it. Either way, they're an anti-feature

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90124392
Nobody needs to sell you anything, just use it if you want to. Here are my reasons:

I generally have a language or two for each category of task. I'll use JavaScript on the frontend, and either JavaScript, Python or Java on the backend. I also have what I call a "tooling" language, and I use it for CLI tools and stuff like that. I generally pick a language that handles cross platform compilation to a binary in a reasonable way. Right now that language happens to be Go. Maybe in 5 years it will be Crystal, I don't know. It won't change anything for me though, I'll just start writing in Crystal. All of the tools I wrote in Go are still going to work without me having to think about Go anymore, because they are just binaries. Make sense?

So basically, I don't care about Go. I just use it because it is here.

last_replies.com:
>>90128075
Since everyone just copies what the first guy was doing, and the first guy usually never bothers at least setting up automated tests.

I've worked with a crapton of legacy shit code bases in the past and now, and it's always the same. The """testing""" is just some weird manual test done on a test environment that's usually broken in some way.

Just relax, figure out which functions or parts of the code you need to update. Then first set up automated tests.

Go mock everything like databases, file systems, or other services. Get your tests first finished and then start refactoring.

Also if you have documentation, cross reference it with the source code because usually documentation is wrong.

I wanted my movies to look like crap, but VHS filters always seem to get it wrong
This simulates the limited chroma bandwidth of analog video:

ffplay -i "$1" \
    -vf "scale=640:-1, \
    telecine, \
        pad=640:480:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2, \
    noise=alls=10:allf=t, \
    geq=lum(X\,Y):cb(X*16\,Y):cr(X*16\,Y), \
    gblur=sigma=2, \
    geq=lum(X\,Y):cb(X/16\,Y):cr(X/16\,Y)"

I don't mean "just" as in "just go model it bro". It's that the final result is better in every way that you'd rather just go through the hassle of modelling it. last_replies.com:
Adobe Acrobat's OCR is breddy gud in general, but I need something which allows for customization.

I need to process old-ass Japanese studies, and besides low-quality scans and atrocious OCR by the publisher (thanks, J-Stage!), I have to deal with kyujitai characters, AND weird variants of these characters, AND the occasional weird glyph from otherwise sensible fonts, AND worst of all, the oldest studies are in vertical, right-to-left reading order but with Western characters fucking sideways.

This is clearly too much for Acrobat's OCR to properly handle. However, studies have strict editorial guidelines, so there's little to no visual variance between the papers of the same publications. So I think that AI-training is overkill, all it would require for good OCR would be informing the software which fonts and/or specific glyphs are used and a graphical template so it can spot text boxes and know when the text is vertical etc. I figure this is the sort of thing which already has existing specialized software for it but which most people have no idea about, so I come to you to ask for recommendations.

Sadly (or luckily) it doesn't work like this. The point of the license is to retroactively override other licenses, which is not legal. While it is possible that AI may eventually be able to perform some tasks currently done by software engineers, it is unlikely that it will be able to completely replace human engineers in the foreseeable future. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/technology/open-source-software-host-fosshost-shutting-down-as-ceo-unreachable/

Open source software hosting and cloud computing provider Fosshost will no longer be providing services as it reaches end of life.

Fosshost project volunteers announced the development this weekend following

>months of difficulties in reaching the leadership including the CEO.

Users are being urged to immediately backup their data and migrate to alternative hosting platforms.

An abrupt shut down, unreachable CEO, lack of funds
UK-based non-profit Fosshost has been providing services to several high profile open source projects like GNOME, Armbian, Debian and Free Software Foundation Europe (FSFE) completely free of charge. But that will soon change as the project reaches end of life.

As of this week various fosshost.org links are are returning 404 (not found) error messages as the service is on its way out.

"At this time, Fosshost is deeply sorry to announce we are no longer able to continue offering our services," states a notice seen today by BleepingComputer on fosshost.org website.

"Due to circumstances outside of the control of the Fosshost volunteers, we are now in a situation where we cannot guarantee our servers will stay online, and in fact expect them to go offline shortly."

"Because of this, we strongly recommend all Fosshost tenants to backup their data immediately, and migrate elsewhere as soon as possible."

The vague notice and the tweet generated much confusion among the community members who were unable to understand the real reason behind Fosshost's shut down.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
"We are unable to pay for co-location costs, and that's why our servers will go offline as [Thomas Markey our CEO is unreachable," a purported Fosshost volunteer is seen commenting on a YCombinator Hacker News post.

The commentator suggests that Markey, who has been unresponsive over the past six months, is the only person with access to bank accounts with funds required to operate Fosshost.

It is worth noting that Fosshost is a Community Interest Company (CIC) formally registered with Companies House, England. As such, its management is still responsible for filing annual regulatory paperwork. Failing this, Fosshost, like any other incorporated organization, could be stricken off from the companies register with additional penalties incurred for the directors.

BleepingComputer has approached both Fosshost and Markey in advance for comment.

Fosshost suffered from a single point of failure
What started in 2020 as a passion project of its CEO Thomas Markey quickly evolved into a cloud computing platform adopted by the open-source community because of its reliability, scalability and provision of global hosting infrastructure.

By December 2021, Fosshost had as many as 250 open-source projects utilizing the service to develop, build, test and compile software.

But its continued increased dependence on the CEO meant Fosshost inadvertently suffered from a single point of failure.

Granted, Fosshost volunteers may have finally been compelled to throw in the towel, early warning signs of Fosshost's internal management chaos began emerging this year.

By August, Fosshost had reached "an untenable situation with its current supplier commitments and obligations" forcing it to phase out its AArch64 as a service offering before the month ended.

In the same announcement Fosshost stated its current management, governance and leadership team were "under review."

By September, Fosshost had suspended its applications citing scalability issues.
